intro: Brassica heleniana, commonly known as the Greek mustard, is a flowering plant in the mustard family, Brassicaceae. It is native to the eastern Mediterranean region and is characterized by its upright, branched stems and yellow flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and produces small, round pods containing several seeds. Its leaves are alternate, lobed, and have a peppery scent when crushed. Brassica heleniana is often cultivated for its edible leaves and seeds, which are used in traditional Mediterranean cuisine.
